comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Barratt O'Hara (1882-1969) was the young lieutenant governor of Illinois (1913-1917); much later in life, he served in Congress: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barratt_O%27Hara bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=O000053 His papers are at the University of Illinois Chicago: www.uic.edu/depts/lib/specialcoll/services/rjd/findingaid... Mrs. O'Hara was the former Florence Hoffmann; they married in 1906, and had at least three sons. In 1913, Lt. Gov. Barratt O'Hara was in a scandal, accused of immorality after meeting a woman at a hotel. O'Hara was head of the Vice Committee at the time, making this an especially juicy story for the newspapers. He also seems to have written a history of heavyweight boxing (published in 1909). books.google.com/books?id=ZXg9AAAAYAAJ&dq=Barratt+o%2...

comment.author: 61849735@N00
comment._content: Gotta love that muff she has.  Is it fox?

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Other pictures of him: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/hec2009004980/ hdl.loc.gov/loc.ndlpcoop/ichicdn.n063383 www.ilstatehouse.com/portraits_409.htm www.life.com/image/50402385 collectibles.bidstart.com/US-Politics-Governor-Barratt-O-... (probably online only temporarily)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The 1913 scandal certainly didn't derail his political career. On Dec 6, 1964, the NYT reported that he was the oldest member (at 82) of the U.S. House of Representatives and provided a lively biographical piece. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20A13F934591273... (requires subscription) According to NYT of April 12, 1966, select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70610F634541A74... he offered to retire if he could not survive 6 rounds with any of the 15 newsmen at a news conference!! (requires subscription) But he lost the 1968 election and died in 1969. NYT Obituary was on August 12, 1969 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20614F93C5D1A7B... (requires subscription)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: I haven't found any reason for him to be in the news on 4/6/1914 in particular. The the [Chicago] Day Book chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/beta/search/pages/results/list... reveals nothing close to that date. But later that month, the Day Book reports that he was assembling a company of volunteers to go Mexico. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1914-04-23/ed-... and on May 6, 1914, he opened offices for a campaign (to be unsuccessful) for the US Senate chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1914-05-05/ed-...

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Here's a snippet about something he and his wife planned to do around that time, according to the Appeal from Saint Paul, Minnesota. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83016810/1914-04-18/ed-... "In order to study labor conditions in cotton mills of the east and south Lieutenant Governor Barratt O'Hara and Mrs. O'Hara will work for two months or more at the looms by the side of the common laborer. The lieutenant governor's identity will not be known."

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thanks swanq and pennylrichardsca for all your interesting information on lieutenant governor of Illinois, Barratt O' Hara and for the photographs that confirm his identity.  We will include some of the information in the description when we update.
